title: 114_hr2899
content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism appointed by the Secretary. Permanent staff with expertise in technical, media, communications, or marketing backgrounds will be assigned or hired. Support for the Office will be provided within various components of the Department. The Secretary appoints liaisons within various Department components to the Office for Countering Violent Extremism. The Assistant Secretary is responsible for coordinating activities across all Department offices to counter violent extremism. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism coordinates activities within the Department to counter violent extremism by identifying risk factors, populations targeted by extremist propaganda, and managing outreach to at-risk communities. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism manages outreach activities directed towards at-risk communities and ensures relevant information informs efforts to counter violent extremism. They also develop a Department-wide strategy guiding policies and programs, including a counter-messaging program leveraging technology. The Department's counter-messaging program utilizes various technologies and social media platforms to counter violent extremism. Additionally, they engage in outreach activities and use cooperative agreements with various partners. The Department's activities to counter violent extremism include engagement, outreach, cooperative agreements with partners, and the development of outcome-based metrics to evaluate programs. These efforts prioritize respecting privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties. The Department is developing outcome-based metrics to evaluate programs and policies to counter violent extremism. The Department is maximizing resources, coordinating with other agencies on countering violent extremism, and providing guidance on grant usage. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism works with the Federal Emergency Management Agency to administer grants for countering violent extremism, outlined in a memorandum of understanding. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, establishes a grant program for eligible community groups to create counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, along with other agencies, will provide an implementation plan for a grant program targeting violent extremism, outlining eligibility and application criteria, award methodology, and monitoring procedures. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit an annual report to Congress for the next five fiscal years on the Office for Countering Violent Extremism, detailing grant eligibility, award methodology, and monitoring procedures. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will provide Congress with annual reports for the next five fiscal years on the Department's programs and policies for countering violent extremism in the United States, including budget details and employee numbers. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will provide Congress with annual reports detailing budget allocations, activities, outcome metrics, outreach efforts, grants awarded, and training related to countering violent extremism programs. The Department conducted outreach with organizations, awarded grants, and provided training to counter violent extremism. Details on personnel and funding levels for the Office, analysis of activities adapting to the threat environment, protection of civil rights and liberties, and evaluation of grant program effectiveness are included in the report. The report includes an evaluation of the grant program's effectiveness in countering violent extremism and how the Office incorporated lessons learned from other departments and agencies. The term 'violent extremism' is defined as ideologically motivated terrorist activities, and $10,000,000 is authorized for the Office for Countering Violent Extremism annually.
